Headline.Para: Maximum temperatures in Singapore rising faster in cool months than in warm months

LeadPara.Para: The cool respite people in Singapore enjoy at the end of the year is becoming increasingly short-lived, as global warming bares its teeth.
According to the weatherman, December and January's mean and highest daily maximum temperatures have gone up the fastest, compared with hotter months.

TailParas.Para: Meteorological Service Singapore (MSS) records show that the daily maximum temperature in the months of December and January shot up to 35.2 deg C this decade, up from the 33.1 deg C in the 1980s.
In comparison, the figure for February and March, among the hottest months of the year, was 35.5 deg C this decade - up from 34.7 deg C in the 1980s.

"This shows that the gap in extreme warm temperatures between the cooler and warmer months has become narrower," said Dr Muhammad Eeqmal Hassim, senior research scientist at the MSS Centre for Climate Research Singapore.
"We are currently conducting studies to understand why the trend is happening, but this is consistent with the effects of global warming," he added.

To help people plan their activities at a time when weather patterns are becoming increasingly erratic, the MSS is developing a weather prediction model for heavy rain or high temperatures, for instance.
Currently, it releases such information in real time.
Dr Muhammad Eeqmal, 36, spoke to The Straits Times ahead of today's release of MSS' annual climate assessment for last year.

The report shows that the mean temperature recorded last December was 27 deg C, which was 0.6 deg C higher than the long-term average for that month. This was the highest monthly mean temperature anomaly registered last year.

Studies are still being conducted to understand reasons behind this.
One possible factor could be a weather phenomenon known as the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO).
This has two main effects over Singapore: In its active phase, it brings rain. In its dry phase, warmer and drier conditions are expected.
"There was a fairly strong dry MJO phase over Singapore throughout December last year, bringing warmer conditions over Singapore," said Dr Muhammad Eeqmal.
Also, while last year was not the country's hottest on record, it was nonetheless the warmest non-El Nino year. El Nino is associated with hotter and drier weather in the region.

The mean annual temperature last year was 27.7 deg C. This was lower than the mean annual temperatures for the two previous years of 28.4 deg C in 2016 and 28.3 deg C in 2015, which were marked by strong El Nino events.
It is still too early to tell whether temperatures will soar to new heights this year. This is because an El Nino event, if any, usually develops from the middle of the year, said Dr Muhammad Eeqmal.
